summary.seg: This composite manuscript of three parts contains medical treatises and recipes in Latin and Middle English, including excerpts from the Liber de Sinthomatibus Mulierum that was part of an ensemble of texts that was known under the title Trotula.

The manuscript also contains magical texts. The most significant text among these is the Liber de angelis annulis karectibus et ymaginibus planetum (Book of Angels, Rings, Characters, and Images of the Planets), which provides detailed instructions for conjuring angels. The manuscript also features a number of added instructions with angelic characters, charms, and an elaborate necromantic instruction for a ritual aimed at raising the soul of a deceased person.

The necromantic instruction has been transcribed by M.R. JamesJames, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, who used it as the basis for his publication The Experiment: A New Year's Ghost Story in 1931. Although James's transcription is accurate overall, he has misidentified the name of one of the spirits on whose permission the ritual's success relies. The spirit whose name James transcribes as 'Raffaell', presumably the Archangel Raphael, in fact is called 'Assaell', referring to the fallen angel Azazel. With this correction it has been possible to identify the necromantic instruction as a copy of a work that circulated widely in magical manuscripts in late medieval and early modern England.

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: The manuscript consists of three separate parts, made of paper, but the third part also contains three parchment leaves

foliation.p: 15th-century foliation, with corrections and supplements made in 20th century:
foliation.note: 35 omitted in 15th-century foliation and 40 repeated: errors corrected in 20th century.
The image displayed at f. [i] shows a stub of paper that has been inserted as part of the conservation of the manuscript.

Numbers i, 85-88, 90-91, 93-96 and 117-118 are missing from the modern foliation and have been assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library).
Folio ii consists of a torn leaf that has been repaired with modern blank paper: the original torn leaf has been separately foliated as 'iii' but this number has been ignored in this record.

note.p: Collation formula by the hand of H.L. Pink, c. 1958 (inside of the lower cover).
Notes on the loss of leaves at various points in the volume (ff. ii recto, 84v, 89v, 92v, 116v, 153v) by H.L. Pink.

binding.p: Quarter binding of brown leather with marbled paper sides; made by Douglas Cockerell and SonDouglas Cockerell and Son (Firm), Grantchester, August 1970, as indicated by an inscription on the inside upper cover by H.L. Pink.
A former spine label of red Russia leather with the gold-stamped inscription 'Miscelleanea Medica MS' has been pasted on the inside upper cover.
Binding height: 225 mm; width: 145 mm; depth: 35 mm.

provenance.p: Sir Thomas Knyvett Knyvett, Thomas Sir, 1539-1618: Knyvett's shelfmark is inscribed in the lower margin of f. 153v: 'Sed ― 53'. See McKitterick (1978), p. 163 (MS 53).
Thomas Knyvett (1596-1658) Knyvett, Thomas, 1596-1658: grandson of Sir Thomas Knyvett 1539-1618, inherited this manuscript together with Knyvett's collection. See McKitterick (1978), pp. 33-34..

John Knyvett (1623-1673) Knyvett, John, 1623-1673: great-grandson of Sir Thomas Knyvett 1539-1618 and son of Thomas Knyvett (1596-1658), inherited this manuscript together with Knyvett's collection. See McKitterick (1978), p. 36 .

Thomas Knyvett (d. 1693) Knyvett, Thomas, d. 1693: great-great-grandson of Sir Thomas Knyvett 1539-1618 and son of John Knyvett (1623-1673), inherited this manuscript together with Knyvett's collection. Thomas died without heir and the Knyvett library was fragmented after his death: 57 of Knyvett's manuscripts had been acquired by John Moore [see below] by 1698. See McKitterick (1978), p. 37.
John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 195 (inscribed on f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736 on the inside upper cover.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Margaret Connolly Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo), The Index of Middle English Prose, 17 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009) and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.11.45, ff. 1r-128v

msItem.title: Thesaurus pauperum (imperfect)
msItem.incipit: 1r Ad pustulas capitis curandas: Ad pustulas capitis sandandas. lauetur sepe capud ubi camomilla trita cocta hic nichil est melius
msItem.explicit: 62v sanitatem mentis et corporis recipere mereamur Qui cum patre
msItem.note: Ends with two prayers, beginning Domine Jhesu qui es omnium vera salus and Deus qui mirabiliter homines creasti.

msItem.title: Charm for extracting splinters
msItem.rubric: 62v Carmen ad spinam extrahendam vel os vel ferrum vel aliquid aliud in una bestia, bestia existente in aure siue in aliquo membro homine
msItem.incipit: 62v + In nomine patris \etcaetera/ te marathe mean deinde dic ter pater noster et aue maria et similiter Credo in deum deinde iste carmen. Roth de consequeth. Roth te marathe mean. marathe mean ren nthi of N.
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Liber de Sinthomatibus Mulierum, Chapters 64-128
msItem.rubric: 62v Hic secuuntur qudam capitula trotule de passionibus mulierum
msItem.incipit: 62v De nimia caliditate mulierum: Contigit aliquando matricem distemperari in caliditate
msItem.explicit: 80v Salsum autem [sic, 'lac' omitted] aut male redolens infantis nutrimento non est
msItem.note: Extracted from the so-called Trotula, an ensemble of three works, one of which is the Liber de Sinthomatibus Mulierum (Book on the Conditions of Women).

msItem.title: Liber de necessarijs ad differendum in practica necessaria ad differendum
msItem.rubric: 80v Incipit liber de necessarijs ad differendum in practica necessaria ad differendum secundum practico secundum magistrum R.
msItem.incipit: 80v Electuaria frigida ad caliditatem curandum competentia
msItem.explicit: 82r et. j. cum partibus aque calide. Explicit

msItem.title: Cardinalis medicus
msItem.incipit: 82r O medice accedens ad infirmum quem nunquam uidisti
msItem.explicit: 84v lapis lazuli et huius hec omnia diligenter considera et attendas
msItem.finalRubric: 84v Explicit libellus Magistri Cardinalis docens purgans quatuor humores

msItem.title: De dosibus medicinarum
msItem.author: Johannes Stephanus
msItem.note: Imperfect due to loss of folios '85'-'88' and '90'-'91'.

msItem.title: Treatise on the human body
msItem.incipit: 92r Homo de humo factus est constat ex humoribus

msItem.title: Instructions for conjuring angels with magic characters
msItem.incipit: 98v Angelus solis Michael Sigillum ☉ [Characters] planeta ☉ signum ♌ leo / nomen quarti celi / Machen
msItem.note: These instructions were added in the late 16th or early 17th century; they are identical to those found in Henrici Cornelii Agrippae Ab Nettesheym Opera Duos Tomos Concinne Digesta Quibus Post Omnium Editiones Novo Accessit Ars Notoria (c. 1630), pp. 465, and 467.

msItem.title: Two magical methods for gaining a woman's love
msItem.incipit: 112v Recipe crines tres ut quatuor virginis caste et complicentur
msItem.explicit: 112v et si ea ex eodem bibat non mutato potu certissimum est sequetur voluntatem tuam
msItem.note: Added in the late (?) 16th century.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains three Middle English recipes for tartary water, a man who has lost his nature, migraine.

listBibl.bibl: For an item list of the Middle English recipes, see Connolly (2009), pp. 66-67 (nos 1-3)

msItem.title: Untitled medical tract
msItem.explicit: 121r cum melle et ponatur sub sole et administretur etcaetera

msItem.title: Treatise on phlebotomy
msItem.explicit: 126r Colera regnat in die et flemna semper in nocte - hec regula vera est

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains Middle English recipes for healing the eyes and strangury ('stranguriam', corr. for 'sturuguriam' in Connolly (2009), p. 67 [no. 6])

Two Latin recipes for curing a headache and blurry vision caused by reuma on f. 128r are attributed to a physician named Albon (Quod D. Albone), perhaps Edmund Albon, "doctor of physick", who was rector of the church of St John the Baptist, Garboldisham, Norfolk, in 1478 (see Francis Blomefield, 'Hundred of Giltcross: Snarehill-House', in An Essay Towards A Topographical History of the County of Norfolk, Volume 1: Containing the Hundreds of Diss, Giltcross, Shropham, the Burgh of Thetford, Grimeshoe, Wayland, and Forehoe (London: Miller, 1805), p. 271.

listBibl.bibl: For an item-list of the Middle English recipes, see Connolly (2009), pp. 67-68 (nos 4-8).

msItem.title: Charm for toothache
msItem.incipit: 128v Write ether of these sayinges of on syde of þe paper and þe name of þe partye greued on þe other syde of þe paper and if þe payne be in þe upper chawe then pricke þe paper on þe syde þe name is written aboue, but if þe payne be benethe, then pricke it beneathe
msItem.note: Full transcription; added in the (?) 16th century by the same hand that copied the next item.

msItem.title: Charm for an unspecified purpose [Sage Leaf Charm]
msItem.incipit: 128v Gather iij leaues of sage in þe hower of Venus, and say to þe fyrst when þou gather it in nomine patris quaesiui te, to þe second in in nomine filii inveni te to þe tird in nomine spiritus sancti sollico te, In folio priori inscribe Christus vincit in 2o Jahan [sic] predicat, in 3o Angelus nunciat [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription, except for the last line which has not been read because the text has been crossed out; added in the (?) 16th century by the same hand that copied the previous item.
Copies of this charm in other manuscripts are intended for healing fevers.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto; including the watermarks of a rooster, crown, bull's head, and letter 'd'.

list.item: Quire 112-1 (ff. ii-10: 1st leaf, before f. ii, not present)
Quire 812-10 (ff. 89-92: leaves 1-4, before f. 89, and 6-7, after f. 89, and 9-12, after f. 92, missing)
Quire 1012-2 (ff. 119-128: leaves 1-2, before f. 119, not present)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in frames of brown ink on the right-hand lower corners of the last versos of quires.

supportDesc.condition: Water damage throughout, but without affecting the text.

layout.seg: No ruling. Single columns, except for ff. 97r-116v which are written in double columns. 33-35 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Written in a single hand writing in a cursive script with both Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Headers with titles at the top of the page rubricated in red ink.

origin.origDate: Copied in the second half of the 15th century

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.11.45, ff. 129r-144v

msContents.textLang: Latin and Middle English with dialectal features that have been located to Lincolnshire (LALME I:66)

msItem.title: Collection of practical, medical, and alchemical recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes nineteen Middle English recipes.

listBibl.bibl: For more details, see Connolly (2009), p. 68 [no. 68]

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: This recipe belongs to the collection of medical recipes in Latin and Middle English on ff. 140r-144v and is copied by the same hand.

listBibl.bibl: For more details, see Connolly (2009), p. 68 [no. 69]

msItem.title: Medical tract (fragment)
msItem.textLang: Latin, but with the names of herbs in Latin and Middle English

msItem.title: Liber de angelis annulis karectibus et ymaginibus planetum
msItem.rubric: 134v Hic incipit liber de angelis annulis karecteribus et ymaginibus planetarum
msItem.incipit: 134v Signum admirabile experimentorum dixit Messayaac et incipit cum adiuncto altissimi et est mirabile signum et ualde admirandum in quo sunt secreta altissimi
msItem.explicit: 139v ex alia parte fac ymaginem illius mulieris et post suffumiga earn et inhuma in fossa alicuius ignoti
msItem.finalRubric: 139v Explicit secreta astronomie de sigillis planetarum et eorum figuris
msItem.note: At the beginning of the text is a colophon: 'Ad mea principia tibi dico salue maria quod Bokenham'.

The text ends with the following note: 'Nota a luna prima ad 14 videliect ad omnia experimenta si uolueris ad odium fac subh hora saturni uel martis si ad amorem pacem uel propter certam causam que me mouit carecteres planetarum et signorum scribere omisi quod Bokenham'.

The name Willelmus is written on the top of f. 136r; Lidaka speculates that the scribe was William Bokenham, the author of two works on urine in London, Wellcome Library, MS 408, where he is claimed to be a monk from Norwich Holy Trinity or St Giles with a degree in medicine from Bologna.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with Latin rubrics, also including a few macaronic and Latin recipes
msItem.note: One recipe on f. 140v may be attributed to Bartholomaeus Anglicus (Ex libro Bartholomei). It begins: 'Homo inter omnia animalia praecipue sompniat'
Copied by a single hand, except for two recipes (Contra Constipacionem et Collicam and Contra Sciaticam) on f. 144v that have been copied by a different hand.

listBibl.bibl: For more details, see Connolly (2009), p. 68 [no. 69]

msItem.title: Copy of a letter
msItem.incipit: 142r Worschipfull sir I comaund me unto ȝow wit all min hert
msItem.explicit: 142r to all othir gude felows And ȝow haffe euer in hisse kepynge
msItem.note: Written vertically and running alongside the medical recipes in the preceding item; in the letter the sender seeks to arrange the return of an English copy of More Arthure (an inglische buke es cald mort arthur as ȝe may se wrytten of my hand in þe last end of þe buke) from Syr William Cuke preste of Byllesbe via John Salus of Lyn [identified by A.I. Doyle as John Salus [Saluz] who is who is identified in records as a burgess of Lynn c. 1426-45].

msItem.title: A necromantic ritual to raise the spirit of the dead
msItem.rubric: 144r (lower margin) An experiment most often proued true to fint out tresure hidden in þe ground, theft, manslaughter or anie other thynge
msItem.incipit: 144r Go to þe graue of a ded man and three tymes call hym on his nam at þe hed of þe graue, and say þou N. N. N. I coniure þe, I require þe, and I charge þe bi þi christendome, þat þou hast taken and receyued at þe font stone, and by þe power and might of þe father and of þe sonne, and of þe hollie ghost, þat þou takest leaue of þe Lord Assaell and Nares and thou askest leave this night to come and tell me trewlie of þe tresure þat lyeth hid in such a place or in what place it is, or in what place it lyeth, how I may best com therby, or by what manner of meanes and wayes. Then take of þe earth of þe graue at þe dead bodyes hed, and knitt it in a lynnen cloth, and put it under þe right eare, and sleape ther uppon, and whersoeuer þou lyest or slepest, þat night he wyll com and tell þou trewlie in wakyng or sleping, so þat þou shalt have a uerie iust knowledge of þi desyre whatsoeuer þou shall aske hyme
msItem.note: Full transcription; the text has been added in the (?) 16th century.
For other copies, see Harms (2019) [without this manuscript].

supportDesc.condition: Stains and dirt covers the page on f. 129r. The upper right-hand corners have been torn off and repaired with blank paper.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only, on ff. 129r-139v. No ruling on ff. 140r-140v. 47 lines (165 x 110 mm) to the page, written below top line, on ff. 129r-139v; and 23-27 (165-185 x 135 mm) on ff. 140r-140v.

handNote.p: The recipes on ff. 129r-133v are written by a single hand in a small Anglicana script.

The recipes on ff. 133v and 140r-144v are written by a single hand in a large Anglicana script. However, two recipes at the top of f. 144v seem to be written by another hand writing in a large script that has both Anglicana and Secretary features.
The fragmentary medical treatise on f. 134r is written by a single hand in a large Anglicana script.
The magical treatise on f. 135v-139v is written by a single hand in a script predominantly with Anglicana features.
The letter concerning the Mort D'Arthur that is written vertically on f. 142r is written by a single hand in a cursive script with Anglicana and Secretary features.
The added necromantic ritual in the lower margin of f. 144r is written by a hand writing in a small Secretary script.

decoNote.p: Magic squares, one with characters (so-called Zagam figure), and the others with numbers organised in grids on ff. 137v, 138r (2x), 138v (2x), 139r (2x), 139v.
The recipes on ff. 129r-133v feature one large (3 line) black initial 'A' outlined in red ink on f. 129r.
The magic treatise on ff. 135v-139v features small black initials (1 line) highlighted in red ink.
The recipes on ff. 133v and 140r-144v, feature small (1 line) initials in brown ink higlighted in red ink on with one on f. 141v featuring a human face in red ink.
Small capitals in brown ink highlighted in red ink in the fragmentary treatise on f. 134r.
Underlining in red ink in the recipes on ff. 129r-133v, the fragmentary treatise on f. 134r, and the magical treatise on ff. 135v-139v .
Paraphs in black ink higlighted in red ink on ff. 129r-133v.

origin.origDate: Copied in the second quarter or second half of the 15th century

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Dd.11.45, ff. 145r-153v

msContents.textLang: Latin, Middle English, and Middle French

msItem.title: Synonyma list of herbs in Latin and English
msItem.textLang: Middle English, Latin and Middle French
msItem.incipit: 145r Alleluya panis cuculi payn de cuculle wodsowre stubwort
msItem.explicit: 153v Quinqueuernia ribworth Quinque folium fuye leued ges
msItem.note: Ending incompletely in the letter Q.

supportDesc.support: Parchment (ff. 145 and 152r-153v) and paper folded in quarto with an unidentified watermark

list.item: Quires 1216-7 (ff. 145-153: leaves 10-16, after f. 153, are missing)

signatures.p: Leaf signatures 'aiij' and 'aiiij' in the lower right-hand corners of f. v and 148r.

supportDesc.condition: The upper right-hand corners of the paper leaves have been torn off and repaired with blank paper.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only. Single columns. 32 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand in a cursive script predominantly with Anglicana features.

decoNote.p: One large (5-line) initial in red ink within a frame of brown ink on f. 145r.
Small capitals in red or brown ink throughout.
The text's first 7 lines are rubricated in red ink.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
